The expression vector for the deletion mutant pHisΔAΔD (Fig. 2A) was constructed as described for the full-length CT (10Kozaki A. Kamada K. Nagano Y. Iguchi H. Sasaki Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10702-10708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). For coexpression of the Δα and Δβ polypeptides to produce the CT complex in E. coli, ΔaccA and ΔaccD cDNAs were bicistronically inserted into the pET-19b vector containing a decahistidine tag (His tag), which allows a fused protein to be purified by a nickel column. First, the ΔaccD cDNA was ligated to the XhoI/BlpI site of pET-19b, and then the ΔaccA cDNA was ligated to theXhoI/NdeI sites of the pET-19b vector carrying the ΔaccD fragment. In the resultant pHisΔAΔD, the His tag was fused to the N terminus of the Δα polypeptide. The His tag was not removed from the recombinant Δα throughout the experiments. After transformation of the E. coli BL21 (DE3) strain (Novagen) with the expression vectors, cells were grown in an LB medium, and the proteins were induced and purified according to the method described (10Kozaki A. Kamada K. Nagano Y. Iguchi H. Sasaki Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10702-10708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). From the cell pellets of a 1-liter culture, about 3 mg of recombinant protein was obtained. The recombinant proteins of the full-length or the deleted wild-type CT were stable and stored at −80° C for characterization. The mutant proteins eluted from a nickel column with a solution containing 150 mm imidazole, 500 mm NaCl, and 20 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.9) were unstable and were immediately used for the enzyme assay and SDS-PAGE. The deleted wild-type CT was dialyzed against the buffer containing 50 mm Tricine-KOH (pH 8), 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, and 0.5 mm DTT. Fifty µl of the dialysate (285 µg) was separated with a Superdex 200 column using a SMART system (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Immunoblot analysis was done as described previously (10Kozaki A. Kamada K. Nagano Y. Iguchi H. Sasaki Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10702-10708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). The antibodies against the α polypeptide were also prepared using the method described (10Kozaki A. Kamada K. Nagano Y. Iguchi H. Sasaki Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10702-10708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). The antibodies against the β polypeptide were prepared using an oligopeptide containing 15 amino acid residues from 399 to 413 of β polypeptide as described elsewhere (11Sasaki Y. Hakamada K. Suama Y. Nagano Y. Furusawa I. Matsuno R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25118-25123Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). CT activity was measured by the reverse reaction method as described elsewhere (10Kozaki A. Kamada K. Nagano Y. Iguchi H. Sasaki Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10702-10708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). The carboxyl transfer from [2-14C]malonyl-CoA to biotin methyl ester was measured. The resultant [14C]acetyl-CoA was evaporated, and the residual [2-14C]malonyl-CoA was determined. A CT fraction in a total of 50 µl of reaction mixture (100 mm Tricine-KOH (pH 8), 10 mm biotin methyl ester, 125 µm malonyl-CoA (0.64 kBq), 37.5 µg of bovine serum albumin) was incubated at 30 °C. After 0 and 20 min of incubation, 20 µl of the mixture was transferred to a tube containing 5 µl of 6 n HCl to terminate the reaction. The mixture was heated to dryness at 98 °C for 20 min in a draft chamber, dissolved in 25 µl of H2O, and applied to Whatman 3MM paper (1 × 1 cm). The difference between radioactivity at time zero and after 20 min of incubation was designated as CT activity. Specific activity is expressed as µmol/min/mg of protein. Proteins eluted from a nickel column (diluted to 1 mg/ml) were alkylated by incubating with 50 mm iodoacetic acid (Sigma) for 10 min at 37 °C. The alkylated proteins were treated with an SDS sample loading buffer in the presence and absence of 720 mm 2-mercaptoethanol. The proteins (about 0.5 µg) were run on SDS-PAGE (7.5 or 10% gel for the deletion mutant and 5% gel for the full-length enzyme) and analyzed on immunoblots probed with either the anti-α polypeptide or the anti-β polypeptide IgG. Pea seedlings (Pisum sativum cv. Alaska) were grown in a 16 h light/8 h dark cycle at 23–25 °C. Plants (8 days old) were kept in darkness for 16 h (dark-adapted plants) and were then exposed to 2 h of white light at 60 µE/s/m2 (light-adapted plants). From the dark- or light-adapted plants, intact chloroplasts were isolated and ruptured as described previously (7Kozaki A. Sasaki Y. Biochem. J. 1999; 339: 541-546Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). All procedures for dark-adapted plants were performed in a dark room under a dim green safety light. The soluble proteins from the lysed extracts were precipitated by ammonium sulfate and stored at −80 °C until use. Pea CT and its recombinant enzyme were redox-regulated in vitro (6Sasaki Y. Kozaki A. Hatano M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 11096-11101Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar, 10Kozaki A. Kamada K. Nagano Y. Iguchi H. Sasaki Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10702-10708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), suggesting the presence of redox-sensitive cysteines in the α and β polypeptides consisting of 825 and 590 amino acid residues, respectively. Fig.1 A shows schematically the position of cysteines deduced from pea accA andaccD cDNAs and the conserved domain in E. coli. N-terminal 310 amino acids of the pea α polypeptide were conserved in E. coli with 81% similarity (47% identity), and C-terminal 278 amino acids of the pea β polypeptide, excluding the reiterated sequence, were conserved in E. coli with 78% similarity (39% identity). The other domains absent from E. coli counterparts are not always conserved among plant proteins. There are two cysteines at positions 247 and 267 in the pea α polypeptide. Alignment shows that the sequences around these cysteines are highly conserved (Fig.2 B); Cys-247 is found in higher plants, and Cys-267 is found in all sequences available. In pea β polypeptides, there are 11 cysteines. Five of them in the N-terminal domain are not conserved among plant proteins (data not shown), but six cysteines in the C-terminal domain are considerably conserved. Four of them, at positions 230, 233, 249, and 252, are found in all the counterparts available and form a motif, CX 2CX 12–15CX 2C. Cysteine at position 442 is found only in pea, and cysteine at 466 is found in all photosynthetic organisms available. Taking into account the redox-insensitive properties of E. coli CT, such a sequence comparison does not directly predict the redox-sensitive cysteines in both the α and β polypeptides. There are 13 possible cysteines involved in redox regulation (Fig. 1 A), and we attempted to reduce them. To investigate whether the domains not conserved in E. coli, namely, the C-terminal half in the α subunit and the N-terminal half in the β subunit, are necessary for redox regulation, we prepared enzymes in which these sequences were deleted, using an expression plasmid, pHisΔAΔD (Fig. 2 A), and examined the redox sensitivity. The eluate partially purified by a nickel column showed redox-sensitive CT activity. The specific activity was 0.366 unit. The eluate exhibited three major bands of 52, 45, and 44 kDa by Coomassie Brilliant Blue staining (Fig. 2 B). A band of 44 kDa reacted with antibodies against the α polypeptide, agreed with the calculated molecular mass, 44.3 kDa, and was identified as His tag Δα. Both 52- and 45-kDa bands reacted with antibodies against the β polypeptide. Determination of the N-terminal sequence of the 52- and 45-kDa bands revealed that the 52-kDa band corresponded to the Δβ protein starting from the predicted first methionine at position 220 (Fig.1 B-b). The N-terminal sequence of the 45-kDa polypeptide started from serine at position 259, suggesting that the third methionine at position 258 was recognized as another starting point. The calculated molecular masses of the Δβ and a polypeptide starting from serine 259 (Δβ*) were 41.7 and 37 kDa, respectively, and the observed size was about 8–10 kDa larger than the calculated value. Such a shift in molecular mass on SDS-PAGE was observed for the full-length β subunit and was attributable to the intrinsic amino acid sequence (11Sasaki Y. Hakamada K. Suama Y. Nagano Y. Furusawa I. Matsuno R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25118-25123Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Usually the 52-kDa band was denser than that of the 45 kDa, and Δβ was the major product. To estimate the molecular size of the deleted CT, the partially purified eluate was separated by gel filtration in the presence of DTT. The peak CT activity appeared in fraction 16. Coomassie Brilliant Blue staining and immunoblotting of separated fractions revealed a peak of His tag Δα, Δβ, and Δβ* polypeptides at fraction 16. A peak composed of only the His tag Δα polypeptide was not found, unlike the expression of full-length polypeptides (10Kozaki A. Kamada K. Nagano Y. Iguchi H. Sasaki Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10702-10708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), suggesting that most of the expressed His tag Δα formed a complex with Δβ or Δβ*. The molecular size of the deletion mutant at fraction 16 estimated from the standard proteins was about 250 kDa and was approximately one-half the size of the full-length CT, 490 kDa. The calculated molecular mass of (His tag Δα)2Δβ2 was also approximately one-half that of the full-length CT, (His tag α)2β2, and the molecular composition of the deleted CT was probably (His tag Δα)2Δβ2 or (His tag Δα)2Δβ*2. Two forms of the deleted CT were obtained by expression of pHisΔAΔD. To determine the form(s) having CT activity, we constructed another plasmid to express Δα and Δβ* polypeptides starting from the methionine at position 258. The eluate obtained by expression of this plasmid showed no CT activity. This result indicates that the measurable activity by expression of pHisΔAΔD is the complex of His tag Δα with Δβ but not that of Δβ* polypeptides. The deleted sequences from 220 to 257, which contain a CX 2CX 12–15CX 2C motif conserved among all the β polypeptides, are required for catalytic activity but not for association with the Δα polypeptide. This is not a case in which a zinc finger motif is usually required for complex formation. It is likely that the CX 2CX 12–15CX 2C motif is important for catalytic activity. We examined the sensitivity of the deleted CT partially purified to the redox state and compared it with that of the full-length CT. In this experiment, the effect of a known reductant of S–S bonds, DTT, was tested. DTT activated the enzyme in a profile similar to that of the full-length enzyme (Fig. 2 D). The monothiol 2-mercaptoethanol did not activate the enzyme efficiently. These results indicate that the deletion mutant was sensitive to the redox state, like the full-length CT (9Sasaki Y. Kozaki A. Ohmori A. Iguchi H. Nagano Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 3937-3940Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar), and that the redox-sensitive cysteines were located in the Δα and Δβ polypeptides. Thus, the deleted sequences, the C-terminal half of the α polypeptide, and the N-terminal half of the β polypeptide are not necessary for redox regulation and may have some other functions. The number of possible cysteines was reduced from 13 to 8. To identify the redox-sensitive cysteines in the deleted CT, a set of mutants, each with a single substitution of cysteine to alanine, was constructed, and the requirement of each mutant CT for DTT was tested. There were no significant differences in the efficiency of expression and purification of all mutants compared with the deleted wild-type enzyme. However, solubility differed with different mutant enzymes. Most mutant enzymes were precipitated under low ionic strength or by freezing. Therefore, each enzyme activity was determined using freshly eluted fraction from nickel column. The relative specific activity of mutants in either the presence or absence of 8 mm DTT was determined (TableII). The deleted CT is redox-sensitive, and if a cysteine involved in redox regulation is replaced, the resultant mutant enzyme is expected to be converted to a redox-insensitive form. We surveyed such an enzyme active in the absence of DTT. In the presence of DTT, the mutant proteins retained varying levels of activity. Substitutions of Cys-267 in Δα and Cys-466 in Δβ had modest effects, retaining more than 50% of the wild-type activity. Other mutant enzymes were more impaired, retaining only 0–30% of the wild-type activity, suggesting that alanine replacements of cysteine residues does not satisfy the structural requirements at these sites for enzyme folding and the substrate binding. In particular, Cys-233 or -252 in a CX 2CX 12–15CX 2C motif is probably required for catalytic activity. In the absence of DTT, only two mutants, the substitution of Cys-267 in the Δα and the substitution of Cys-442 in the Δβ polypeptides, were active and their activities were almost equal to those occurring in the presence of DTT. These results indicate that Cys-267 in Δα and Cys-442 in Δβ are required for redox regulation.Table IICT activity of cysteine to alanine mutantsPosition of cysteine replaced by alanineRelative activity−DTT+DTTDeleted CTNone (wild type)0100α 247032α 2676277β 23008β 23303.7β 249018β 25200β 44266β 466051Full-length CTNone (wild type)0100α 2672.45.7β 4421.22.4Specific activities of 100% of the deleted CT and the full-length CT in the presence of 8 mm DTT were 0.366 and 0.151 unit, respectively. Each value represents the average of three independent measurements at two enzyme concentrations (S.D. range 10%). Open table in a new tab Specific activities of 100% of the deleted CT and the full-length CT in the presence of 8 mm DTT were 0.366 and 0.151 unit, respectively. Each value represents the average of three independent measurements at two enzyme concentrations (S.D. range 10%). To confirm the role of the two cysteines at the same position in the full-length CT, we generated mutant enzymes with a substitution of cysteine by alanine and measured their activity (Table II). Although the CT activity was low, measurable activity was found in the absence of DTT, indicating that Cys-267 in the α subunit or Cys-442 in the β subunit is required for redox sensitivity and that the redox sensitivity of the full-length enzyme is probably mediated exclusively through these two cysteines. The molecular size of the deleted CT is about half that of the full-length CT, and the specific activity of the deleted CT corrected for the difference of molecular size was comparable with that of the full-length. The extra sequences, the C-terminal region of the α polypeptide and the N-terminal region of the β polypeptide (Fig. 1 A), do not play an important role for exhibition of the enzyme activity. The low activity of these mutants suggests that the replacement of the cysteine by alanine may bring about inappropriate conformation for catalytic activity, probably by interacting with the extra sequences of the full-length CT. The interaction, which does not occur in the wild-type full-length enzyme, is somehow harmful for the expression of the full activity by preventing efficient substrate binding or subunit-subunit interaction. Each subunit had only one cysteine responsive to redox, suggesting that an intermolecular but not an intramolecular disulfide bond is formed under nonreduced conditions. The molecular composition of CT is probably α2β2, and there are possible intermolecular disulfide bonds between homodimers or heterodimers. To determine which type of S–S bond was formed, SDS-PAGE analysis of several recombinant enzymes was performed in the presence or absence of the reducing agent 2-mercaptoethanol. To prevent rearrangement of disulfide bonds during treatment with a sample loading buffer, SH groups were alkylated with iodoacetic acid. The modified proteins were denatured and separated by SDS-PAGE in the presence or absence of 2-mercaptoethanol and probed with antibodies against the α or β polypeptides (Fig. 3). When the deleted wild-type enzyme was analyzed, the band of His tag Δα (44 kDa) observed in the presence of 2-mercaptoethanol was partly shifted to about 125 kDa in its absence (Fig. 3 a). The bands of Δβ (52 kDa) and Δβ* (45 kDa) were also shifted to about 125 kDa. These results suggest that both the His tag Δα and Δβ polypeptides formed intermolecular S–S bonds, probably between His tag Δα and Δβ or Δβ*. The apparent molecular mass, about 125 kDa, was larger than the sum of the two bands, probably because of the slow migration of this alkylated and S-S-bonded polypeptide. To further confirm the S–S bond between the two molecules, a CT enzyme consisting of a full-length α and Δβ was expressed, and the intermolecular S–S bond was analyzed (Fig. 3 b). In this enzyme, the α polypeptide is twice as large as Δα, and we expected shifted bands larger than 125 kDa, which would react with both anti-α and anti-β polypeptide antibodies. The number of cysteine residues was the same as that of the deleted wild-type CT, and its redox sensitivity was similar to that of the wild type (data not shown). In the absence of 2-mercaptoethanol, both anti-α and anti-β polypeptide IgG reacted with the two shifted bands at ∼200 kDa, supporting the idea that the α polypeptide formed an S–S bond with Δβ or Δβ* under nonreducing conditions, although the apparent molecular size of the shifted bands was again larger than the sum of the two polypeptides. These results support the idea that the shifted bands are heterodimers of His tags α and Δβ or Δβ* and suggest that the S–S bond is formed between Cys-267 in α and Cys-442 in Δβ or Δβ*. To confirm the presence of the S–S bond in full-length wild-type CT, we analyzed the CT under nonreducing conditions (Fig. 3 c). The shifted bands of about 230 kDa were observed in both α and β polypeptides, supporting the idea that the S–S bond was formed in full-length CT as expected. The shifted minor bands probably resulted from the β polypeptide, starting from the second and third methionine of the β polypeptide. The remaining α polypeptide was the polypeptide expressed in excess not associated with the β polypeptide (10Kozaki A. Kamada K. Nagano Y. Iguchi H. Sasaki Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10702-10708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). If the disulfide bond is formed between Cys-267 in the Δα and Cys-442 in the Δβ or Δβ*, mutation of these cysteines breaks the disulfide bond and results in the loss of the shifted band under nonreducing conditions. We analyzed the mutants and found that the molecular size of the polypeptides is the same in the presence and absence of 2-mercaptoethanol. We lost the shifted heterodimer bands of His tags Δα and Δβ or Δβ* under nonreducing conditions (Fig. 3, d and e). The results indicate that each cysteine is necessary for an intermolecular S–S bond and that a critical disulfide bond is formed between Cys-267 in the α subunit and Cys-442 in the β subunit. We have shown previously that ACCase from light-adapted plants is in a much more reduced form than that from dark-adapted plants and that light-dependent reduction of ACCase occurs in vivo (7Kozaki A. Sasaki Y. Biochem. J. 1999; 339: 541-546Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). To ensure that the results observed in the recombinant enzyme (Fig. 3) were applied in vivo, we examined disulfide bridge formation in the enzyme by immunoblots of extracts from plants in light or dark (Fig. 4). The shifted bands of about 230 kDa were observed in both α and β polypeptides in the absence of 2-mercaptoethanol, suggesting that both the α and β polypeptides formed a S–S bond in vivo. The disulfide form of about 230 kDa was more abundant in the dark-adapted plants than in the light-adapted plants; the reverse was found for thiol forms of about 98 kDa for α polypeptide and 90 kDa for β polypeptide, suggesting that a light-dependent reduction of the disulfide bond indeed occurred in vivo. Probably the thiol-disulfide exchange observed in vitro is relevantin vivo, although we cannot completely exclude the possibility that a different set of cysteine residues is involved in the S–S bond in vivo. The experiments reported here show that the two cysteines, Cys-267 in the Δα polypeptide and Cys-442 in the Δβ polypeptide, are required for redox regulation of the recombinant CT. The observation appears to be relevant in vivo, and the two cysteines are likely involved in the reductive activation of CT, and therefore in that of ACCase, by disulfide-dithiol interchange. In the light, electrons from photosystem I are shuttled through the electron transport chain to ferredoxin and are transferred to thioredoxins by ferredoxin-thioredoxin reductase and then to ACCase, reducing the disulfide bonds in the CT and resulting in the light activation of fatty acid synthesis. All of the polypeptides encoded by the chloroplast genome form a functional complex with polypeptides encoded by the nuclear genome. For example, ribulose-bisphosphate carboxylase, RNA polymerase, Clp protease, and ATP synthase are composed of chloroplast-encoded and nuclear-encoded polypeptides (12Martin W. Herrmann R.G. Plant Physiol. 1998; 118: 9-17Crossref PubMed Scopus (531) Google Scholar). In these enzymes, the catalytic or structural polypeptides are encoded by the chloroplast genome, and the regulatory polypeptides are encoded by the nuclear genome. The same may be true for pea CT, although further experiments are needed to characterize the precise function of the two subunits. The chloroplast-encoded β polypeptide has catalytic and regulatory functions, and the nuclear-encoded α polypeptide has a regulatory function. To date, we do not know the molecular interaction between catalytic and regulatory polypeptides. A new finding obtained in our experiments indicates that molecular interaction of the two polypeptides is characterized as follows: the nuclear-encoded polypeptide forms a covalent bond with the chloroplast-encoded polypeptide and thereby changes enzyme activity. There are several chloroplast enzymes activated by thioredoxin (13Schürmann P. Jacquot J.-P. Annu Rev. Plant Physiol. Plant Mol. Biol. 2000; 51: 371-400Crossref PubMed Scopus (324) Google Scholar), including fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase, sedoheptulose-1,7-bisphosphatase, phosphoribulokinase, ATP synthase, NADP-dependent malate dehydrogenase, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, and ribulose-bisphosphate-carboxylase activase. The cysteine residues involved in redox regulation are identified by site-directed mutagenesis, and some consensus motifs among plants have been found for each enzyme. However, a consensus motif among enzymes has not yet been found. A comparison of the primary sequences of these enzymes with redox-insensitive cytosolic isoforms or with the redox-insensitive counterpart from different organisms reveals that the redox-sensitive cysteines are located on extra loops or extensions (14Rulland E. Miginiac-Maslow M. Trends Plant Sci. 1999; 4: 136-141Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar). Light-regulated NADP-dependent malate dehydrogenase possesses sequence extensions at both the N- and C-terminal ends compared with the constitutive active counterpart and two cysteines at the N terminus and two cysteines at the C terminus are involved in redox regulation (15Issakidis R. Miginiac-Maslow M. Decottignies P. Jacquot J.-P. Cretin C. Gadal P. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21577-21588Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Issakidis E. Saarinen M. Decottignies P. Jacquot J.-P. Cretin C. Gadal P. Migniac-Maslow M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3511-3517Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Chloroplast fructose bisphosphatase possesses an insertion containing three cysteines compared with the constitutive active cytosolic enzyme and two of them are involved in redox regulation (17Jacquot J.-P. Lopez-Jaramillo J. Chueca A. Cherfils J. Lemaire S. Chedozeau B. Miginiac-Maslow M. Decottignies P. Wolosiuk R. Lopez-George J. Eur. J. Biochem. 1995; 229: 675-681Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar, 18Jacquot J.-P. Lopez-Jaramillo J. Migniac-Maslow M. Lemaire S. Cherfils J. Chueca A. Lopez-Jaramillo J. FEBS Lett. 1997; 401: 143-147Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). In contrast to these enzymes, different features are found for pea ACCase. First, the molecular structure of pea chloroplast ACCase differs considerably from redox-insensitive cytosolic ACCase (1Sasaki Y. Konishi T. Nagano Y. Plant Physiol. 1995; 108: 445-449Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 2Ohlrogge J. Browse J. Plant Cell. 1995; 7: 957-970Crossref PubMed Scopus (1258) Google Scholar), and we cannot propose a possible origin of redox-sensitive cysteines, although there are some similarities in their CT domains. Second, the regulatory cysteine in the α polypeptide is not located in the plant-specific extra domains but in domains conserved among organisms, reflecting the differences from other chloroplast enzymes in terms of the evolutionary origin of redox sensitivity. Third, intermolecular disulfide bonds among different polypeptides are involved in redox regulation, whereas intramolecular disulfide bonds are involved in the other chloroplast enzymes. Available sequence data show that the Cys-267 in the α polypeptide is conserved among organisms but the Cys-442 in the β polypeptide is found only in pea. Other organisms have a serine at this position. Replacement of Cys-442 by serine resulted in CT with very low activity (data not shown) suggesting that Cys-442 is important for pea CT. At present, we cannot propose a possible consensus sequence of CT for redox regulation. There is a possibility that this type of redox regulation is unique to the pea, although spinach (19Hunter S.C. Ohlrogge J.B. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1998; 359: 170-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar) and tobacco ACCases 2Y. Madoka, and Y. Sasaki, unpublished observation. are redox-regulated, and another set of cysteines may be responsible in other species. In the case of sedoheptulose bisphosphatase, the redox-sensitive cysteines of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii were predicted to be different from those of plants (20Anderson L.E. Huppe H.C. Li A.D. Stevens F.J. Plant J. 1996; 10: 553-560Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Replacement of Cys-247 or -267 in the α polypeptide by serine resulted in mutants of low activity, less than 3% of the deleted wild-type (data not shown), whereas the corresponding replacements by alanine residues allowed the more active CT, about 30–80% of the wild-type (Table II). Serine residues at these positions are not compatible with the formation of a functional complex of CT activity, but alanine replacement of Cys-247 or Cys-267 satisfies the structural requirement at these sites for CT folding and stability. Similar results were obtained for replacement of the cysteine by serine in the β polypeptide. Serine is a hydrophilic amino acid, and alanine, like cysteine, is hydrophobic. It is likely that the hydrophobicity of cysteine plays an important role in the functional folding of CT. Such results were reported for rhodopsin (21Karnik S.S. Sakmar T.P. Chen H.-B. Khorana H.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 8459-8463Crossref PubMed Scopus (347) Google Scholar) and small soluble proteins such as trypsin inhibitor (22Staley J.S. Kim P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 1519-1523Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar) and lysozyme (23Inaka K. Taniyama Y. Kikuchi M. Morikawa K. Matsushima M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 12599-12603Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A conserved motif, CX 2CX 12–15CX 2C, forms a putative zinc finger motif. The deletion of this domain suggests that this motif is required for catalytic activity, probably binding metal ions. A preliminary experiment to identify the metal ion by flame reaction showed the presence of Zn but not of Fe. 3A. Kozaki, K. Mayumi, and Y. Sasaki, unpublished observation. Further experiments are needed in order to understand the precise roles of the α and β subunits. We thank H. Mori for analysis of protein sequences, H. Iguchi for analysis of the intermolecular disulfide bond, and M. Hirose and Y. Nagano for discussions.

Insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) are crucial for many aspects of development, growth, and metabolism yet control of their activity by IGF-binding proteins (IGFBPs) remains controversial. The effect of IGFBP-1 depends on its phosphorylation status; phosphorylated IGFBP-1 inhibits IGF actions whereas the nonphosphorylated isoform is stimulatory. In order to understand this phenomenon, we purified phosphorylated IGFBP-1 from normal human plasma by immunoaffinity chromatography. Unexpectedly, the resulting preparation enhanced IGF-stimulated 3T3-L1 fibroblast proliferation, due to the presence of a co-purified protein of ≈700 kDa. Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-mass spectrometry and Western immunoblotting analysis identified this co-purified protein as α2-macroglobulin (α2M). Anti-α2M antibodies co-immunoprecipitated IGFBP-1 from human plasma and from125I-IGFBP-1·α2M complexes formed in vitro. The 125I-IGFBP-1/α2M association could be inhibited with excess unlabeled IGFBP-1. Surface plasmon resonance analysis indicated that α2M preferentially associates with the phosphorylated isoform of IGFBP-1 and that when complexed to α2M, IGFBP-1 can still bind IGF-I. These findings have functional significance since α2M protects IGFBP-1 from proteolysis and abrogates the inhibitory effect of phosphorylated IGFBP-1 on IGF-I stimulated 3T3-L1 cell proliferation. We conclude that α2M is a binding protein of IGFBP-1 which modifies IGF-I/IGFBP-1 actions resulting in enhanced IGF effects. In line with its role in regulating the clearance and activity of other growth factors, we predict that α2M has a novel and important role in controlling the transport and biological activity of IGFs.

The crystal structure of Escherichia coli 6-hydroxymethyl-7,8-dihydropterin pyrophosphokinase (HPPK) in complex with MgADP has been determined at 1.5-Å resolution with a crystallographic R factor of 0.191. The solution structure of HPPK in complex with Mg2+ and β,γ-methyleneadenosine 5′-triphosphate (MgAMPPCP) has been determined using a simulated annealing protocol with 3,523 experimental NMR restraints. The root mean square deviation of the ensemble of 20 refined conformers that represent the solution structure from the mean coordinate set derived from them is 0.74 ± 0.26 Å for all backbone atoms and 0.49 ± 0.22 Å when residues Pro14, Pro44–Gln50, and Arg84–Pro91 are excluded. Binding of MgADP causes significant changes in the conformation and dynamical property of three loops of HPPK that are involved in catalysis. A dramatic, unusual conformational change is that loop 3 moves away from the active center significantly with some residues moving by >17 Å. The binding of MgADP also stabilizes loop 1 and loop 3 but makes loop 2 more mobile. Very similar conformational and dynamical changes are observed in the NMR solution structure of HPPK·MgAMPPCP. The conformational and dynamical changes may play important roles in both substrate binding and product release in the catalytic cycle. The crystal structure of Escherichia coli 6-hydroxymethyl-7,8-dihydropterin pyrophosphokinase (HPPK) in complex with MgADP has been determined at 1.5-Å resolution with a crystallographic R factor of 0.191. The solution structure of HPPK in complex with Mg2+ and β,γ-methyleneadenosine 5′-triphosphate (MgAMPPCP) has been determined using a simulated annealing protocol with 3,523 experimental NMR restraints. The root mean square deviation of the ensemble of 20 refined conformers that represent the solution structure from the mean coordinate set derived from them is 0.74 ± 0.26 Å for all backbone atoms and 0.49 ± 0.22 Å when residues Pro14, Pro44–Gln50, and Arg84–Pro91 are excluded. Binding of MgADP causes significant changes in the conformation and dynamical property of three loops of HPPK that are involved in catalysis. A dramatic, unusual conformational change is that loop 3 moves away from the active center significantly with some residues moving by >17 Å. The binding of MgADP also stabilizes loop 1 and loop 3 but makes loop 2 more mobile. Very similar conformational and dynamical changes are observed in the NMR solution structure of HPPK·MgAMPPCP. The conformational and dynamical changes may play important roles in both substrate binding and product release in the catalytic cycle. 6-hydroxymethyl-7,8-dihydropterin pyrophosphokinase α,β-methyleneadenosine 5′-triphosphate β,γ-methyleneadenosine 5′-triphosphate 6-hydroxymethyl-7,8-dihydropterin heteronuclear single-quantum coherence nuclear Overhauser effect nuclear Overhauser effect spectroscopy root mean square deviation 6-Hydroxymethyl-7,8-dihydropterin pyrophosphokinase (HPPK)1 catalyzes the transfer of pyrophosphate from ATP to 6-hydroxymethyl-7,8-dihydropterin (HP, Scheme FSI), leading to the biosynthesis of folate cofactors (see Fig. 1 in Ref. 1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Because the folate pathway is essential for microorganisms but absent from mammals, HPPK, like other enzymes in the pathway, is an important target for developing antimicrobial agents. HPPK belongs to a class of enzymes that catalyze the pyrophosphoryl transfer reaction (2Switzer R.L. Boyer P. The Enzymes. 3rd Ed. Academic Press, New York1974: 607-629Google Scholar). Although the mechanisms of many kinases that catalyze monophosphoryl transfer have been extensively characterized, little is known about the mechanisms of pyrophosphokinases. As a small (158 residues, ∼18 kDa), stable, monomeric protein, Escherichia coli HPPK is an excellent model system for studying the mechanisms of enzymatic pyrophosphoryl transfer. We have recently determined the crystal structures of ligand-free (apo-) E. coli HPPK (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) and its complex with HP, α,β-methyleneadenosine 5′-triphosphate (AMPCPP), and two Mg2+ ions (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar) at 1.5 and 1.25 Å resolution, respectively. Hennig and co-workers (4Hennig M. Dale G.E. D'Arcy A. Danel F. Fischer S. Gray C.P. Jolidon S. Müller F. Page M.G.P. Pattison P. Oefner C. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 287: 211-219Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar) have determined the crystal structure ofHaemophilus influenzae HPPK in complex with an HP analog at 2.05-Å resolution. Stammers and co-workers (5Stammers D.K. Achari A. Somers D.O. Bryant P.K. Rosemond J. Scott D.L. Champness J.N. FEBS Lett. 1999; 456: 49-53Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar) have determined the crystal structure of E. coli HPPK in complex with an HP analog, ATP, and two Mg2+ ions at 2.00-Å resolution. Comparative analysis of the crystal structures of the apo-HPPK and its ternary complex has revealed the interactions of the enzyme with the substrates at the atomic resolution and the dramatic substrate-induced conformational changes involving three catalytic loops (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). It appears that the complete active center of HPPK is assembled only after both substrates bind to the enzyme. However, how the catalytic center is assembled is not known. It appears that some catalytic residues cannot move into their catalytic positions because of steric constraints. In this paper, we present the crystal structure of HPPK·MgADP at 1.5-Å resolution and the NMR solution structure of HPPK·MgAMPPCP. The two structures reveal a dramatic, unusual movement of loop 3 and other significant changes in the conformation and dynamical property of HPPK. The dramatic substrate-induced movement of loop 3 is unusual because it moves away from the active center. Comparative structural analysis suggests that the structures reported here may represent an intermediate conformation required for both substrate binding and product release in the catalytic cycle. E. coli HPPK was purified as previously described (6Shi G. Gong Y. Savchenko A. Zeikus J.G. Xiao B. Ji X. Yan H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1478: 289-299Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). Crystals of HPPK·MgADP were grown in hanging drops at 19 ± 1 °C. The protein solution contained 4 mg/ml HPPK, 5 mm MgATP in 10 mm Tris buffer (pH 8.0), and the reservoir contained 30% polyethylene glycol 4000, 0.2 m NaAc in 0.2 mTris buffer (pH 8.5). The 4-µl hanging drops contained equal volumes (2 µl) of protein solution and reservoir solution. Two rounds of seeding produced diffraction-quality crystals. X-ray diffraction data were collected from a single crystal at beamline X9B of the National Synchrotron Light Source (Brookhaven National Laboratory) on a MarResearch image plate system at 100 K maintained with an Oxford Cryosystem. The crystal diffracted to 1.5 Å. X-ray data were processed using HKL2000 (7Otwinowski Z. Minor W. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 276: 307-326Crossref PubMed Scopus (38572) Google Scholar). The crystal belongs to space groupC 2 with unit-cell dimensions a = 79.12, b = 52.84, c = 36.63 Å, and β = 103.44°. Data collection and statistics are summarized in Table I. The asymmetric unit contains one complex, and the crystal contains ∼38% solvent. The structure was solved with the molecular replacement technique using AmoRe (8Navaza J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. A. 1994; 50: 157-163Crossref Scopus (5029) Google Scholar). The apo-HPPK structure (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) was used as the search model after the solvent molecules were removed. Model building and adjustment were carried out with the program O (9Jones T.A. Zou J.Y. Cowan S.W. Kjeldgaard M. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. A. 1991; 47: 110-119Crossref PubMed Scopus (13011) Google Scholar). Initial refinement was done with X-PLOR (10Brünger A.T. Rice L.M. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 277: 243-269Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar), and the final stage of the refinement was done with SHELXL-97 (11Sheldrick G.M. Schneider T.R. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 277: 319-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (1886) Google Scholar). All data within the resolution range of 20–1.5 Å were used with 21,914 reflections (∼95%) for structure refinement and 1,114 reflections (∼5%) for R free calculations. Residues 44–48 of loop 2 were not included in the refinement due to the lack of electron density. The peptide chain containing residues 85 and 86 was built with two distinct conformations based on the difference electron densities. The two conformations were assigned equal probabilities, which were verified by the comparable temperature factors resulting from subsequent refinement. The final R free was 0.263, and the crystallographic R factor was 0.191 for all reflections within 20.0 and 1.5 Å (Table II). The structure was assessed using PROCHECK (12Laskowski R.A. MacArthur M.W. Moss D.S. Thornton J.M. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 1993; 26: 283-291Crossref Google Scholar), showing that 92.5% of the residues are in the most favored regions and no residue falls into disallowed regions on the Ramachandran plot.Table ISummary of x-ray data collection for the HPPK·MgADP complexX-ray source (rotating anode)X9B, NSLS, BNLDetector (image plate system)MarResearch (345)D min(Å)1.5No. of measurements83,381No. of unique reflections23,029Redundancy3.6Overall completeness (%)97.7Last shell completeness (%)85.4OverallI/ς(I)18.6Last shellI/ς(I)1.97R scaling1-aRscaling = Σ‖I − 〈I〉‖/ΣI. Open table in a new tab Sequential resonance assignments have been previously reported (13Shi G. Gao J. Yan H. J. Biomol. NMR. 1999; 14: 189-190Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar). The NMR samples contained ∼1.5 mm HPPK, 8 mm AMPPCP, and 40 mmMgCl2 in 20 mm sodium phosphate, pH 7.4 (pH meter reading without correction for isotope effects). All NMR data were acquired at 25 °C on a Varian Inova 600 spectrometer. Approximate interproton distance restraints for the NMR structure determination were derived from the NOE data, including homonuclear two-dimensional NOESY, three-dimensional 15N-edited NOESY-HSQC, and 13C/15N-edited NOESY-HSQC spectra. The mixing time was 150 ms for all the NOESY experiments. Most of the NOE cross-peaks were picked from three-dimensional15N-edited NOESY-HSQC and13C/15N-edited NOESY-HSQC spectra using the program NMRView (version 4.0.3) (14Johnson B.A. Blevins R.A. J. Biomol. NMR. 1994; 4: 603-614Crossref PubMed Scopus (2678) Google Scholar). Only a few NOE-cross peaks involving aromatic protons were picked from the homonuclear two-dimensional NOESY spectrum. The integrated peak volumes were converted into approximate interproton distances by normalizing them against the calibrated volumes of NOE peaks between backbone protons within the identified β-sheet regions. The upper limits of the interproton distances were calibrated according to the equationV a = V b(r b/r a)6, where V a and V b were the volumes and r a and r b the distances. The distance bounds were set to 1.8–2.7 Å (1.8–2.8 Å for NOE cross-peaks involving amide protons), 1.8–3.3 Å (1.8–3.5 Å for NOE cross-peaks involving amide protons), 1.8–5.0 Å (1.8–6.0 Å for NOE cross-peaks involving amide protons) and 1.8–6.0 Å (1.8–7.0 Å for NOE cross-peaks involving amide protons) corresponding to strong, medium, weak, and very weak NOEs, respectively. Pseudoatom corrections were made for nonstereospecifically assigned methylene and methyl resonances (15Wüthrich K. Billeter M. Braun W. J. Mol. Biol. 1983; 169: 949-961Crossref PubMed Scopus (1008) Google Scholar). An additional 0.5 Å was added to the upper bounds for methyl protons. Structure calculations were performed on a Sun Ultra 1 work station using the program CNS (version 0.9) (16Brünger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. DeLano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.-S. Kuszewski J. Nilges N. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallog. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16967) Google Scholar) with the provided CNS task files. Preliminary structures were calculated with a hybrid distance geometry-simulated annealing protocol based on the CNS task file dg_sa.inp. Final structures were calculated with an ab initio simulated annealing protocol based on the CNS task file anneal.inp. MgAMPPCP was not included in the structure calculations. An iterative strategy was used for structure refinement. In each round of structure refinement, newly computed NMR structures were employed to assign more NOE restraints, to correct wrong assignments, and to loosen the NOE distance bounds if spectral overlapping was deduced. Another round of structure refinement was then carried out with the modified NMR restraints. A total of 50 structures were generated. Twenty structures with no NOE violations >0.25 Å were selected for analysis by the programs INSIGHT II (version 97) (Molecular Simulations) and PROCHECK-NMR (version 3.4.4) (17Laskowski R.A. Rullmannn J.A. MacArthur M.W. Kaptein R. Thornton J.M. J. Biomol. NMR. 1997; 8: 477-486Google Scholar). The crystal structure of E. coliHPPK in complex with MgADP (Fig.1a) contains 153 of 158 amino acid residues of the polypeptide chain (residues 44–48 are disordered), one Mg2+ ion, one ADP molecule, one phosphate ion, and 258 water molecules (Table II). As revealed by our apo-structure (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), HPPK has a three-layered αβα fold formed by six β strands and four α-helices in the sequence β1-α1-β2-β3-α2-β4-β5-β6-α3-α4 (Fig.1 a). In the center, the six β-strands are organized into an antiparallel β-sheet (β2, β3, β1, and β4) and a β-hairpin (β6 and β5). The angle between the adjacent β4 and β6 is ∼70°. On each side of the central β structure, there are two α-helices. Residues 44–48 in loop 2 are completely disordered, and their occupancy factors are set to zero, as indicated with thedashed line in Fig. 1 a. Two conformations are observed for residues 85 and 86 in loop 3. Although the crystallization was carried out with the presence of MgATP, MgADP (Fig. 1 b) was found in the structure of the complex apparently due to the hydrolysis of the nucleotide. As previously predicted (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) and observed (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 5Stammers D.K. Achari A. Somers D.O. Bryant P.K. Rosemond J. Scott D.L. Champness J.N. FEBS Lett. 1999; 456: 49-53Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar), the adenine base of ADP is positioned in the V-shaped cleft between β4 and β6 and the ribose and pyrophosphate extend along the valley and across β4 and β1 (Fig. 1 a). Two conformations of the ADP molecule are found to have equal probabilities (Fig. 1 b). A few water molecules and a phosphate ion occupy the HP-binding site. The crystallographic R factor is 0.191, and theR free is 0.263 for reflections within the resolution range 20.0–1.5 Å (Table II). The bound ADP has two conformations. The major differences are the positions of the α- and β-phosphates (Fig. 1 b). Fig. 2illustrates the interactions between HPPK and the bound ADP. The binding of the adenosine moiety to HPPK is essentially the same for both ADP conformations, whereas the phosphate chain interacts with the protein with significant differences. For both conformations of the ADP molecule, the adenine base has four strong electrostatic interactions with the protein: N1···N(Ile98), N6···O(Ile98), N6···O(Thr112), and N7···N(Thr112). In addition, residues Leu70, Leu111, His115, and Tyr116 provide hydrophobic interactions with the base, and the sugar moiety has one strong electrostatic interaction with the protein, O2*···O(R110) (Fig. 2). Thus, the adenine is held tightly in the V-shaped cleft between β4 and β6 (Fig.1 a). The phosphate-protein interaction shows significant differences between the two conformations, although some similarities are also found. For both conformations, the β-phosphate oxygen atoms interact with Glu77 through Mg2+ and also interact with Asp97 (Fig. 2). However, the side chains of Asp95 and Arg92 interact with the phosphate groups in conformation b, but not in conformation a (Fig. 2). Arg92 forms a strong and a weak hydrogen bond with O1B (2.4 Å) and O1A (3.2 Å), respectively. Although the core structures of apo-HPPK (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) and HPPK·MgADP (this work) are essentially the same, the conformations of the three flexible loops are significantly different. Fig.3a shows the superposition of the Cα traces of the two structures optimized for 131 out of 158 pairs of Cα atoms. Twenty-seven pairs are excluded for optimization: residues 10–13, 44–53, 81–92, and 149. Residues 10–13 reside in loop 1, which has two conformations in apo-HPPK (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), whereas, in HPPK·MgADP, loop 1 assumes one conformation that is not any of the two conformations in the apo-structure. Residues 44–48 are completely disordered. Although residues 49–53 have a defined conformation, it is different from the conformation of loop 2 in the apo-enzyme. The most striking difference is in loop 3 (residues 81–92) that assumes an even more open conformation in HPPK·MgADP than in apo-HPPK. The Cα atom of Glu87 of loop 3 in HPPK·MgADP is 18.4 Å away from the corresponding atom in apo-HPPK. Recently we have determined the crystal structure of HPPK in complex with HP, AMPCPP (an analogue of ATP), and two Mg2+ions (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). The complex represents a close mimic of a state in which the enzyme is bound with both substrates and two Mg2+ ions required for catalysis. Fig. 3 b shows the superposition of the Cα trace of HPPK·MgADP with that of HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP. The residues that belong to loops 1–3 (Fig.1 a) are excluded for the optimization. The two structures are superimposed very well with a root mean square deviation (r.m.s.d.) of 0.41 Å for the Cα atoms of the optimized residues. The conformations of the three loops are strikingly different between the two structures. When MgADP binds to HPPK, loop 1 moves toward loop 2, whereas loop 3 moves dramatically away from the active center (Fig.3 a). In contrast, when both HP and AMPCPP bind to HPPK, loop 1 moves toward loop 3; both loops 2 and 3 move down toward the active center (Fig. 3 b). Part of loop 2 is disordered in HPPK·MgADP, but the entire loop 2 is well defined in HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP. The largest difference between the two structures is 6.0 Å for loop 1 and 23.4 Å for loop 3, as measured by their Cα atom positions of Ala12 and Glu87, respectively. The adenosine moieties of the bound nucleotides in the two structures are superimposed well, but the conformations of the phosphate moieties are significantly different between the two structures. Stammer and co-workers (5Stammers D.K. Achari A. Somers D.O. Bryant P.K. Rosemond J. Scott D.L. Champness J.N. FEBS Lett. 1999; 456: 49-53Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar) have determined the crystal structure of HPPK in complex with ATP, two Mg2+ions and an HP analog, of which the overall conformation is very similar to that of HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). A total of 3,523 structurally useful distance restraints were obtained from the analyses of the homonuclear two-dimensional NOESY (D2O) and three-dimensional15N-edited NOESY-HSQC and13C/15N-edited NOESY-HSQC spectra (TableIII). Of the NOE restraints, 1,129 were derived from long range NOEs. On average, each residue had ∼22 NOE restraints. The distribution of the NOE restraints is shown in Fig.4. Twenty structures with no NOE violations of >0.25 Å are shown in Fig.5a. The statistics of the structures are summarized in Table III. Except for residues Pro14, Pro44–Gln50, and Arg84–Pro91, the structures are well defined (Fig. 5 a). The precision of the structures (r.m.s.d. of the 20 coordinates) is 0.77 Å for the backbone atoms (N, Cα, C, O) and 1.17 Å for all heavy atoms. When residues Pro14, Pro44–Gln50, and Arg84–Pro91 are excluded, the precision of the structures is 0.49 Å for the backbone atoms and 0.88 Å for all heavy atoms. The distribution of the average r.m.s.d. calculated for the backbone heavy atoms is shown in Fig. 5 b. (Å) of the ensemble of 20 refined structures from the restrained minimized mean structure calculated for the backbone heavy atoms.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) The secondary structure elements and folding of the three structures are essentially the same. The NMR structure of HPPK·MgAMPPCP can be superimposed with the crystal structure of apo-HPPK with an average Cα deviation of 1.85 Å. The major conformational differences are located in loops 1 and 3, and the largest conformational difference is found in loop 3. When the two loops are excluded, the average Cα deviation between the two structures is 1.06 Å. The average Cα deviation between the two structures is 2.86 Å for loop 1 and 9.94 Å for loop 3. The largest Cα deviation is 18.49 Å for the Cα atom of Glu87. In comparison with the crystal structure of apo-HPPK, loop 1 in the NMR structure of HPPK·MgAMPPCP moves toward loop 2, and loop 3 moves away from the active center. Although these loops are less well defined in the NMR structure, the conformational differences in these loops between the NMR structure of HPPK·MgAMPPCP and the crystal structure of apo-HPPK are significant because they are much larger than the variations of the ensemble of the 20 NMR structures. The NMR solution structure of HPPK·MgAMPPCP is rather similar to the crystal structure of HPPK·MgADP (Fig.6). The two structures can be superimposed with an average Cα deviation of 1.11 Å. No Cα deviations, except those of Pro14, Ala86, and Glu87, exceed 2.59 Å. The Cα deviations of Pro14, Ala87, and Glu87 are 5.68, 4.23, and 4.89 Å, respectively. It is clear that MgAMPPCP and MgADP induce very similar conformational changes in HPPK. In both structures, loop 1 moves toward loop 2, and loop 3 moves away from the active center. However, the magnitude of the movement is larger in the NMR structure. The binding of MgADP or MgAMPPCP causes significant changes in the conformations of three catalytic loops in HPPK. The movement of loop 3 is unusual and dramatic. First, the magnitude of the movement is large. In comparison with the crystal structure of apo-HPPK (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), the Cα atoms of loop 3 move by as far as ∼17 Å. Movements of such a magnitude are usually observed in substrate-induced domain closure. Second, the loop moves away from the active center rather than moving in and closing the active center as usually observed in substrate-induced fit. Are the dramatic conformational changes of loop 3 real? The fact that virtually identical loop movements were observed in both crystal and NMR structures indicates that the unusual loop movements indeed occur in solution. To our knowledge, these are the first structures showing that a catalytic loop moves a long distance away from the active center of an enzyme upon the binding of a ligand. The unusual conformational changes of loop 3 cannot be discovered by comparing the crystal structures of apo-HPPK (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) and the ternary complex HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Binding of MgADP or MgAMPPCP also induces significant changes in the dynamical properties of HPPK. Fig. 7shows a plot of the B-factors of the main-chain atoms of the crystal structures of apo-HPPK (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), HPPK·MgADP (this work), and HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Clearly, loops 2 and 3 in apo-HPPK have much higher B values than the rest of the molecule (green line), indicating that the two loops have high mobility. When HPPK is bound with HP, AMPCPP, and two Mg2+ ions, mimicking the catalytic ternary complex, the B-factors of all residues, except a few in the C-terminal region, decrease significantly. The B-factors of loop 2 fall into the average range. The B-factors of loop 3 as well as the C-terminal region are slightly higher than the average B value, but they are within the range of the average B value of apo-HPPK. The B-factor profile of HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP suggests that HPPK becomes much more rigid when both substrates and cofactors are bound. Although loop 3 and the C-terminal region in HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP are slightly more mobile than the rest of the molecule, they are not more mobile than the rigid portion of apo-HPPK. The B-factor profile of HPPK·MgADP is rather interesting. The average B value of HPPK·MgADP is about the same as that of apo-HPPK. The B factors of loops 1 and 3 are significantly lower than those of apo-HPPK, suggesting that binding of MgADP stabilizes loops 1 and 3. In contrast, residues 44–48 of loop 2 are completely disordered, suggesting that binding of MgADP makes loop 2 more mobile. Similar dynamical changes have been observed in our NMR studies of HPPK. Briefly, loops 1 and 2 of apo-HPPK had weak cross-peaks and loop 3 showed no cross-peaks in the 1H-15N HSQC spectrum (13Shi G. Gao J. Yan H. J. Biomol. NMR. 1999; 14: 189-190Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar). It is unlikely that the diminution or disappearance of these cross-peaks was caused by water saturation because the HSQC spectrum was recorded with a “water flip-back” pulse sequence designed to minimize water saturation and dephasing (18Grzesiek S. Bax A. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1993; 115: 12593-12594Crossref Scopus (1015) Google Scholar, 19Zhang O. Kay L.E. Olivier J.P. Forman Kay J.D. J. Biomol. NMR. 1994; 4: 845-858Crossref PubMed Scopus (612) Google Scholar). Rather, it suggests that these loops are flexible and undergo conformational exchange (20Wang L. Li Y. Abildgaard F. Markley J.L. Yan H. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 12727-12736Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). In the presence of MgAMPPCP, all residues of loop 3 showed cross-peaks in the 1H-15N HSQC spectrum. However, the intensities of some cross-peaks of loops 1 and 2 became weaker in the presence of MgAMPPCP. The result suggests that upon the binding of MgAMPPCP, loop 3 is stabilized but loops 1 and 2 become more mobile. 15N relaxation analysis is under way to characterize quantitatively the motional properties of HPPK in various forms. We have shown by comparing the crystal structures of apo-HPPK and the ternary complex that the catalytic center of HPPK is assembled only upon the binding of both substrates (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). However, how the catalytic center is assembled is not clear from comparing the two crystal structures. In apo-form, the side chains of several strictly conserved residues (Gln50, Arg82, and Arg92) point away from the active center (Fig.8a) (1Xiao B. Shi G. Chen X. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 1999; 7: 489-496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). It appears that the side chains of the two arginine residues, especially Arg92, cannot move into the active center without first opening loop 3 (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Thus, additional conformational changes are required during the assembling of the catalytic center. The crystal structure of HPPK·MgADP and the solution structure of HPPK·MgAMPPCP may represent the intermediate conformations required for assembling the catalytic center. The idea is consistent with the ordered bi-bi mechanism suggested by Bermingham and co-workers (21Bermingham A. Bottomley J.R. Primrose W.U. Derrick J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 17962-17967Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). With the further opening of loop 3, Arg92 is able to move into the active center without steric clashes. Loop 3 stays in the intermediate conformation, partly due to the formation of a short hydrogen bond between Arg92 and Asp95 (Fig.8 b). The distance between the two heavy atoms that are involved in the hydrogen bond (NH2 of R92 and OD1 of D95) is 2.68 Å in the crystal structure of HPPK·MgADP. The conformation of the carboxyl group of Asp95 in HPPK·MgADP is very similar to that in apo-HPPK. In the ternary complex (HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP), however, the carboxyl group of Asp95 moves down so that the guanidinium group of Arg92 is able to move further into the active center. The key elements responsible for pulling down the carboxyl group of Asp95 appear to be the two bound Mg2+ ions. One Mg2+ is coordinated with the α- and β-phosphoryl groups of ATP, and the other with the β- and γ-phosphoryl groups of ATP and the hydroxyl group of HP (3Blaszczyk J. Shi G. Yan H. Ji X. Structure. 2000; 8: 1049-1058Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 5Stammers D.K. Achari A. Somers D.O. Bryant P.K. Rosemond J. Scott D.L. Champness J.N. FEBS Lett. 1999; 456: 49-53Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Both Mg2+ ions are coordinated with the carboxyl groups of Asp95 and Asp97 and with water molecules to fulfill the octahedral coordination. There is only one Mg2+ in HPPK·MgADP. The location of Mg2+ in HPPK·MgADP is different from that of either of the two Mg2+ ions in HPPK·HP·MgAMPCPP (1.63 Å between Mg1 and Mg2, and 4.89 Å between Mg1 and Mg3; Fig.8 b), and so is its coordination. The Mg2+ in HPPK·MgADP is coordinated with two oxygen atoms of the β-phosphate of ADP and atom OE2 of conserved Glu77 (Fig. 2). The sealed active center needs to be opened up after the chemical reaction so that products can leave the active center. Transient kinetic analysis has shown that product release is rate-limiting in HPPK-catalyzed reaction. 2Y. Li, Y. Gong, G. Shi, J. Blaszczyk, X. Ji, and H. Yan, unpublished results. The conformational and dynamic changes revealed by this work may also play an important role in dissembling the active center and thereby releasing the products. We thank Dr. Z. Dauter for assistance during x-ray diffraction data collection.

The structure of the serpin, plasminogen activator inhibitor type-2 (PAI-2), in a complex with a peptide mimicking its reactive center loop (RCL) has been determined at 1.6-Å resolution. The structure shows the relaxed state serpin structure with a prominent six-stranded β-sheet. Clear electron density is seen for all residues in the peptide. The P1 residue of the peptide binds to a well defined pocket at the base of PAI-2 that may be important in determining the specificity of protease inhibition. The stressed-to-relaxed state (S → R) transition in PAI-2 can be modeled as the relative motion between a quasirigid core domain and a smaller segment comprising helix hF and β-strands s1A, s2A, and s3A. A comparison of the Ramachandran plots of the stressed and relaxed state PAI-2 structures reveals the location of several hinge regions connecting these two domains. The hinge regions cluster in three locations on the structure, ensuring a cooperative S → R transition. We hypothesize that the hinge formed by the conserved Gly206 on β-strand s3A in the breach region of PAI-2 effects the S → R transition by altering its backbone torsion angles. This torsional change is due to the binding of the P14 threonine of the RCL to the open breach region of PAI-2. The structure of the serpin, plasminogen activator inhibitor type-2 (PAI-2), in a complex with a peptide mimicking its reactive center loop (RCL) has been determined at 1.6-Å resolution. The structure shows the relaxed state serpin structure with a prominent six-stranded β-sheet. Clear electron density is seen for all residues in the peptide. The P1 residue of the peptide binds to a well defined pocket at the base of PAI-2 that may be important in determining the specificity of protease inhibition. The stressed-to-relaxed state (S → R) transition in PAI-2 can be modeled as the relative motion between a quasirigid core domain and a smaller segment comprising helix hF and β-strands s1A, s2A, and s3A. A comparison of the Ramachandran plots of the stressed and relaxed state PAI-2 structures reveals the location of several hinge regions connecting these two domains. The hinge regions cluster in three locations on the structure, ensuring a cooperative S → R transition. We hypothesize that the hinge formed by the conserved Gly206 on β-strand s3A in the breach region of PAI-2 effects the S → R transition by altering its backbone torsion angles. This torsional change is due to the binding of the P14 threonine of the RCL to the open breach region of PAI-2. reactive center loop plasminogen activator inhibitor urinary plasminogen activator or urokinase stressed-to-relaxed state leukocyte elastase inhibitor root mean square The serpins are an unusual class of protein in that they fold into a metastable structure (the stressed state) that can usually undergo a major structural change to an extremely stable form (the relaxed state) on cleavage by a target protease (1Gettins P. Patston P. Olson S. Serpins: Structure, Function, and Biology. R. G. Landes Co., Austin, TX1996Google Scholar). Most serpins are serine (or cysteine) protease inhibitors that act in a suicide fashion, using the stability of the relaxed state to trap the protease in a nonfunctional covalent serpin-protease complex. The target protease cuts the accessible reactive center loop (RCL)1 on the serpin to produce a covalent acyl intermediate (2Lawrence D.A. Ginsburg D. Day D.E. Berkenpas M.B. Verhamme I.M. Kvassman J.O. Shore J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 25309-25312Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (227) Google Scholar, 3Wilczynska M. Fa M. Ohlsson P.I. Ny T. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 29652-29655Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). The RCL then inserts into β-sheet 2All serpin secondary structure elements are labeled as per Loebermann et al. (17Loebermann H. Tokuoka R. Deisenhofer J. Huber R. J. Mol. Biol. 1984; 177: 531-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (604) Google Scholar). 2All serpin secondary structure elements are labeled as per Loebermann et al. (17Loebermann H. Tokuoka R. Deisenhofer J. Huber R. J. Mol. Biol. 1984; 177: 531-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (604) Google Scholar). A to form the relaxed state. Attached to the RCL, the target protease moves to the base of the serpin, where it is partially unfolded, thus inhibiting its activity (4Huntington J.A. Read R.J. Carrell R.W. Nature. 2000; 407: 923-926Crossref PubMed Scopus (932) Google Scholar, 5Egelund R. Petersen T.E. Andreasen P.A. Eur. J. Biochem. 2001; 268: 673-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). This mode of action, whereby one protein uses the increased stability of an altered conformer to partially unfold a second, covalently bound target protein, is unprecedented in biology. Plasminogen activator inhibitor 2 (PAI-2) is a serine protease inhibitor that belongs to the ov-serpin branch of the serpin superfamily (6Remold-O'Donnell E. FEBS Lett. 1993; 315: 105-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar). PAI-2 is an effective inhibitor of urinary plasminogen activator (urokinase or uPA) and, to a lesser extent, an inhibitor of tissue-type plasminogen activator. PAI-2 has several features that distinguish it from the more widely studied serpins. PAI-2 lacks an N-terminal secretory signal but contains a relatively inefficient internal signal sequence (7von Heijne G. Liljestrom P. Mikus P. Andersson H. Ny T. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 15240-15243Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This produces a distribution where a majority (∼70%) of the protein is nonglycosylated and intracellular, with the rest in a glycosylated, extracellular form. PAI-2 has a unique insertion of ∼30 residues between helices hC and hD (CD loop), which is the site of glycosylation and the site of cross-linking to the cell membrane and also fibrin via transglutaminase action (8Jensen P. Schuler E. Woodrow G. Richardson M. Goss N. Hojrup P. Peterson T. Rasmussen L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15394-15398Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The CD loop also binds a number of largely unidentified cytoplasmic proteins (9Jensen P. Jensen T. Laug W. Hager H. Gliemann J. Pepinsky B. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 26892-26899Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). PAI-2 is expressed by specific cell types including epithelial cells, monocytes/macrophages, and keratinocytes (10Kruithof E. Baker M. Bunn C. Blood. 1995; 86: 4007-4024Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It is expressed at high levels in the skin, hair follicles, gingival cells, the cervix, and placenta. PAI-2 is cross-linked to create the cornified envelope in terminally differentiated epithelial cells, where it forms a proteinaceous coat, with PAI-2 in both the active and relaxed forms (11Risse B. Brown H. Lavker R. Pearson J. Baker M. Ginsburg D. Jensen P. Histochem. Cell Biol. 1998; 110: 559-569Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 12Risse B. Chung N. Baker M. Jensen P. J. Cell. Physiol. 2000; 182: 281-289Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). PAI-2 appears to have several distinct biological functions (10Kruithof E. Baker M. Bunn C. Blood. 1995; 86: 4007-4024Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). To date, complexes between PAI-2 and uPA have not been observed in vivo. Several studies have indicated that the intracellular pool of PAI-2 plays a role in apoptosis (13Dickinson J. Bates E. Ferrante A. Antalis T. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 27894-27904Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (227) Google Scholar, 14Medcalf R. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 12220-12226Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The up-regulation of PAI-2 expression by inflammatory mediators and its high level of expression in macrophages and keratinocytes suggests a role in the regulation of the inflammatory response and wound healing. The high levels of PAI-2 observed in human pregnancy plasma indicate a role in maintenance of the placenta or perhaps embryonic development (15Lecander I. Åstedt B. Br. J. Haematol. 1986; 62: 221-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). However, PAI-2(−/−) null mice exhibit essentially normal development, survival, and fertility (16Dougherty K. Pearson J. Yang A. Westrick R. Baker M. Ginsburg D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 686-691Crossref PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar). Crystallographic studies have been central to understanding serpin function. It was clear from the initial structure of cleaved α1-proteinase inhibitor (relaxed state) that the mechanism of protease inhibition was unusual (17Loebermann H. Tokuoka R. Deisenhofer J. Huber R. J. Mol. Biol. 1984; 177: 531-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (604) Google Scholar). Subsequently determined structures of serpins in various states have led to models for the stressed to relaxed state (S → R) transition, which is central to protease inhibition (18Stein P. Chothia C. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 221: 615-621Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 19Whisstock J.C. Skinner R. Carrell R.W. Lesk A.M. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 296: 685-699Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). The determination of the stressed state structure of a PAI-2 CD loop deletion mutant has contributed to the understanding of the mechanics of this transition, especially with regard to the conserved shutter region (20Harrop S. Jankova L. Coles M. Jardine D. Whittaker J. Gould A. Meister A. King G. Mabbutt B. Curmi P. Structure. 1999; 7: 43-54Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). We have determined the structure of the complex formed by the PAI-2 CD loop deletion mutant with a peptide mimicking the RCL at 1.6-Å resolution. The complex adopts the relaxed state, facilitating a high resolution analysis of the S → R transition in PAI-2. By comparing the Ramachandran plots of PAI-2 in the two states, we have identified key hinge regions that facilitate the transition. These are clustered into three regions coordinating the transition. Recombinant human PAI-2 loop deletion mutant was cloned and expressed in Escherichia coli and purified as described by Jensen et al. (8Jensen P. Schuler E. Woodrow G. Richardson M. Goss N. Hojrup P. Peterson T. Rasmussen L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15394-15398Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This mutant lacks the loop between helices hC and hD (residues 66–98, inclusive, in the PAI-2 gene sequence). In order to generate a relaxed form of the protein, a synthetic peptide with an acetylated N terminus (N-acetyl-Thr-Glu-Ala-Ala-Ala-Gly-Thr-Gly-Gly-Val-Met-Thr-Gly-Arg-OH (Auspep, Australia)), which mimics the RCL loop, was incubated with PAI-2 (1 mg/ml) at a 100-fold molar excess of the RCL peptide in 50 mm NaCl, 50 mm Tris, pH 8.0, at 37 °C for 48 h (21Saunders D. Buttigreig K. Gould A. McPhun V. Baker M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 10965-10971Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). The PAI-2·peptide complex was dialyzed and concentrated to 10 mg/ml prior to crystallization using a vacuum dialysis system (Sartorius) against a buffer containing 5 mm Hepes, pH 7.5, and 100 mm NaCl. All crystals were grown by vapor diffusion using the sitting drop technique at room temperature by mixing equal volumes (3 μl) of protein and reservoir solution (13% polyethyleneglycol 8000, 0.1 mMg(CH3COOH)2, and 0.1 m Hepes, pH 7.5). Large crystals (600 × 500 × 250 μm3) appeared within 3–5 days, belonging to the orthorhombic space group P21212 with unit cell dimensionsa = 93.14 Å, b = 104.16 Å, andc = 41.34 Å. Crystals were cryoprotected by serially transferring them through a set of solutions containing 17% polyethyleneglycol 8000, 0.1 mMg(CH3COOH)2, 0.1 m Hepes, pH 7.5, and increasing concentrations of ethylene glycol (1% up to 16% in 1% steps) prior to freezing directly in liquid nitrogen. Synchrotron data were collected on station 9-2 at Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory using an ADSC Quantum 4 CCD detector with x-rays at 1.0-Å wavelength. Data were integrated using the program MOSFLM (22Leslie A. Moras D. Pojarny A. Thierry J. Crystallographic Computing 5: From Chemistry to Biology. Oxford University Press, Oxford1993Google Scholar) and then scaled and reduced with the program SCALA, which is part of the CCP4 suite of programs (23Collaborative Computing Project 4 Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D. 1994; 50: 760-763Crossref PubMed Scopus (19667) Google Scholar). The structure of the stressed form of PAI-2 was used as a molecular replacement model (20Harrop S. Jankova L. Coles M. Jardine D. Whittaker J. Gould A. Meister A. King G. Mabbutt B. Curmi P. Structure. 1999; 7: 43-54Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar) to provide initial phasing using the program AmoRe (24Navaza J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D. 1994; 50: 157-163Crossref Scopus (5026) Google Scholar). Initial electron density maps showed that the PAI-2·peptide complex adopted the relaxed serpin structure with the peptide inserted as β-strand s4A in β-sheet A. A model was built using the interactive graphics program O (25Jones T.A. Zou J.Y. Cowan S.W. Kjeldgaard M. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. A. 1991; 47: 110-119Crossref PubMed Scopus (12999) Google Scholar) and then improved by several cycles of model building and refinement using both REFMAC (26Murshudov G.N. Vagin A.A. Dodson E.J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D. 1997; 53: 240-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (13712) Google Scholar) and CNS (27Brunger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. DeLano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16915) Google Scholar). The final model consists of PAI-2 residues 2–61, 102–215, 220–270, 274–367, and 378–415, where Cys161 is modified by β-mercaptoethanol; the 14 residues of the RCL peptide plus its N-terminal acetylation; and 440 water molecules. For 15 residues, alternative side chains have been modeled (seven of which are serines). Data reduction and refinement statistics are presented in Table I. Clore G.M. DeLano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. D Biol.
